body: cc @Ocramius, @TysonAndre and others who might have smart thoughts.

Alternatively we could use the keyword `is` (which Hack now uses for runtime type checks):

`(T is string ? string : array<string, string>)`

> There's also the question of what to do if the caller passes through a ?string - I assume both proposals would infer string|array<string, string>, and have equivalent functionality with different syntax.

Yeah

> Pattern matching was another idea I had for syntax for use cases like this. That might also be useful for user-defined functions/methods that act like var_export.

The reason I prefer the originally-proposed syntax is that, even though it's a little more verbose for the end user (the `@template` params have to be given), it fits much more neatly into Psalm's existing mechanics ‚Äì beyond the type parsing, there's not _too_ much extra that needs to be done.

Is the `T` necessary, though? Could it just be

`     * @psalm-return ($x extends string ? string : array<string, string>)`

Even if Psalm did support that syntax, it would still use templates under the hood because templates are well-understood ‚Äì they're bound at call-time, so calculating the resultant type is pretty trivial.

I also find it useful, when venturing into foreign waters, to stay fairly close to a big ship ‚Äì TypeScript, in this instance, which uses `T`.
@Ocramius can you give some more concrete example code? I'm not sure how that would work

Also interesting:

```php
/**
 * @param int|float $a
 * @param int|float $b
 * @return int|float
 * @psalm-match callable(float, int) : float
 * @psalm-match callable(int, float) : float
 * @psalm-match callable(int, int) : int
 * @psalm-match callable(float, float) : float
 */
function add($a, $b) {
    return $a + $b;
}
```

It can also be interesting to verify totality of implementation, and to document anything using constant/flags üëç

Dunno, I think the syntax in https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/issues/3005#issuecomment-602143042 is extremely hard to follow.

Isn't it much easier to match multiple manually declared signatures?

> Isn't it much easier to match multiple manually declared signatures?

No ‚Äì I've just committed a prototype of this to master, and the matching logic for ternary conditional types is (currently at least) very self-contained: https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/commit/6058725256c24841c3d5dad4474696ded73a9968#diff-88aa0097e81fcbafe2955bf5efd0ae34R1270-R1313

Please kick the tyres on this ‚Äì I'm going to keep this ticket open while I work out kinks.

Here's a working example: https://psalm.dev/r/740dcfbf81

repository.name: redaxo
repository.description: REDAXO, a PHP-based CMS since 2004. Both simple and flexible.

body: I don't mind the other syntax if it gets the ball rolling: how does it behave with 3 possible input combinations though? Thinking horrible things like methods that accept bitmasks.
